scenario_title: Single-Event APT-Style Internal Attack via Malware Planting and System Monitoring

why.details: The insider used advanced malware and persistence techniques to monitor the system covertly, seeking either revenge or external payment by exfiltrating valuable business or operational data.

how.description: Copied a disguised malware executable to a system directory using command line.
how.procedure: Privileged user uses admin shell or elevated privileges to transfer a malicious executable into a core OS directory by command-line, bypassing normal deployment processes.
observable_evidence: Command-line invocation (e.g., cmd.exe, bash) copying executable to system directory
Unusual file placement in OS directory that isnâ€™t part of standard deployment
Files with suspicious names or hidden attributes in system folders
how.impact: Initial execution of malware allows adversary to establish foothold and further control activities.

how.description: Modified system registry or startup script to ensure malware persistence after reboot.
how.procedure: Malware or insider modifies registry keys, startup script, or scheduler settings so that malicious code runs automatically after reboot or user login, ensuring long-term presence.
observable_evidence: New entries in Run/RunOnce registry keys pointing to unknown executable
Creation or modification of scheduled task outside normal IT deploy windows
Service or process starts automatically tagged as suspicious or non-standard
how.impact: Persistent presence on host enables covert monitoring and further sabotage without repeated manual action.

how.description: Used command line tools to connect to an unauthorized external server, establishing a hidden remote control channel.
how.procedure: Malware or insider uses a command-line tool or embedded agent to initiate a covert outbound connection to an attacker-controlled server, establishing a remote-control channel for later data exfiltration or monitoring.
observable_evidence: Outbound network connection to non-standard external IP/port after hours
Use of uncommon protocol or port for external connection (e.g., non-443 HTTPS, custom port)
Remote session established from host to external server under privileged account
how.impact: Remote control channel allows adversary to issue commands, exfiltrate data, or manipulate host undetected.

how.description: Used malware to monitor file access patterns and system logs for sensitive data leakage opportunities.
how.procedure: The malware agent monitors file access and system logs to identify sensitive data (e.g., intellectual property, credential stores) and prepares files for exfiltration or further manipulation.
observable_evidence: High frequency file read operations by malicious process on sensitive directories
Access to log files and directories by processes not standard for role
Monitoring or scanning of directories containing IP, credentials or backups
how.impact: Adversary gains intelligence about available data and sets up for significant sabotage or exfiltration operations.
